#Planning and Inspirations

Firstly, I'm not sure if my technical skills are sufficient for this character because I want to create a fully detailed character, from modeling to animation.

It's crucial for me to find an instrumentalist that won't stand out too much.

The violin-like instrument at the Incesaz concert I attended yesterday seems like the most logical choice. Moving the bow back and forth and hitting the right chords in a small area seems easier and more doable than a guitar. Also, the sitting posture while playing this instrument seemed the most original to me compared to others.

Or maybe placing the music sheet right in front of my hand to obstruct the view might be a better option. Also, this didn't seem like laziness but rather a display of cleverness to me.

Violin or stringed instrument

Saxophone with beats

When immersed in music, instead of taking the metro, start dancing

A song synchronized with movements

On November 30, 2023, after a day's break, I decided to make the character a saxophonist. I believe it will be more in sync with the energy of the stage. Plus, adjusting this sound for the project will be easier. I'm not sure how to convey what's in my mind about the guitarist on a guitar, but I can easily convey it humming to the saxophonist. If I can't achieve the sound with artificial intelligence, I'm thinking of collaborating with a saxophonist from Fiverr and basing the entire animation on this sound. These are my current thoughts.

#Blocking the scene and the character

I am going to model my second character from scratch, and since I am not very familiar with the proportions of the human anatomy, I initially drew some reference sketches using the grease pencil. I created two views, one from the front and one from the side.

first blocking character blocking based on those sketches i made

v2

v3

last model blocking

#Setting Proportions

These are the individually adjusted pieces, but they don't fully reflect a chubby character. Therefore, I plan to address this issue after assembling all the blocks. In fact, at this stage, blocking all the features of the character seems to be the most logical step in defining the character's personality. Exploring more in these areas in future projects seems like the most sensible approach.

#Polishing the character

I combined the parts and tried to bring them closer to chubby proportions. By 'chubby,' I mean I added a bit of a belly, and in doing so, I deviated a bit from my original intention, but not too much, it seems :D. As I approach the end of the character, I find myself spending more time on details, but it appears that, in line with the project's purpose, it's best to refrain from unnecessary details as much as possible.

#Clothing

I am considering designing a relatively realistic character, avoiding overly stylized details in the clothing. The stitching will be pronounced, the pockets will be filled, and wrinkles will be designed in a simple manner.

Among the clothing ideas in my mind, there will be a pocketed sporty pair of pants, a raincoat-like top, and very cute stylized shoes.

#Head

I am quite satisfied with the head model I created in the first 4-5 hours; the final result pleased me. Although there is not enough detail in the ear, and I am losing some time in certain areas due to my insufficient knowledge of anatomy, I am hopeful that these issues will be resolved with other projects.

#Head Variations

When it comes to the character's appearance, creating a different variation and performing the same process is much more efficient and effective than making small changes while wondering which one will look better. It is also educational.

After the initial version of the head, I started creating various head variations. This not only reveals different possibilities but also allows me to notice and correct some mistakes in the model later on.

However, my mistake in creating these variations was deviating too much from the initial model. These significant changes made it challenging to preserve the character's original form. Looking back now, I realize that the initial version aligns more closely with the ideal model I had envisioned for the project.

#Body Seperating

I separated the body parts that will be visible when rendered using a face mask.

I separated only the visible parts of the character, both because they are not visible and caused difficulties during animation and rigging. In this image, the feet are included, and at least having the ankles visible seems reasonable. However, I found myself deleting the feet while working on the project :D.

#Retopology

I didn't manually connect the arms because one is high-poly while the other is significantly low-poly, making retopology challenging and impractical. This version meets the requirements of the project.

Retopology turned out to be the most challenging part of the project. The face and other body parts didn't pose much difficulty and were technically sound. However, technical limitations were more prominent in the wrinkles of the pants and jacket. This aspect was not topologically accurate and led to a considerable loss of time. I should consider looking into tutorials or courses to improve in this area.

#Character Rig

I mostly benefited from Pierric Picaut's rigging course, which I watched about half a year ago, for the character rig. I am quite satisfied with the result, as it allows for easy control of the character.

#Tooth, Gum and Tongue

I decided not to add a tongue to this model because it won't be very prominent in the final project, and also, I have limited time.

#Face Expressions

I found it more suitable to create facial expressions using shape keys rather than facial rigging. This is because I lack knowledge on how to create a facial rig, and for my current project, having smiling and blowing expressions is sufficient for me. However, for the next project or those beyond it, I am interested in learning how to create facial rigs.

In the latest version, I made a few adjustments and added five shape keys: eye blink, blowing, slightly asymmetrical smiling, and grinning.

I struggled to achieve a tooth-showing smile. I believe this is due to my limited time and insufficient use of references.

#Character And Clothes Texturing

For the leather, I used two simple grunge maps; one for roughness variation and the other for height variation. The hair is composed of a solid color only. I noticed that I wasn't achieving the desired roughness setting in Substance Painter, and I resolved this issue within Blender.

I kept the character texturing quite simple. Since I wanted to achieve a Hand Painted effect and plan to refine the normal maps with brush strokes, I avoided adding too many details. I only incorporated solid color and roughness variation. I added a few extra details, but their visibility in the final project is minimal.

#Grease Pencil Details

Since I had no knowledge about Grease Pencil rigging, I worked on the Grease Pencil details on the face frame by frame. This was one of the most time-consuming tasks and also quite tedious.

For the other Grease Pencil details on the character's body, I only used the default line art modifier and adjusted the line thickness. In fact, I did this only for the pants. I had plans to do the same for the upper jacket, but due to some technical issues, I couldn't accomplish it. I decided not to add it later.

I am quite pleased with the final result, and I believe that Grease Pencil has added a lot to the project, enhancing its beauty.

#Normal Painting

I replaced all the normal maps of the character with those painted using brush strokes. I may not have set the normal map settings technically perfectly. However, it was important for me to try this for the first time and at least not end up with an unsuccessful result.

For future projects, if I decide to use this technique again, I want to dedicate more time to this process to achieve better results. I didn't spend too much time on this due to my excitement and the uncertainty of whether it would be effective for the project or not.
